evidence.detectionMethod: PCR-SSCP and PCR-heteroduplex analyses followed by sequencing was used to screen all 13 exons of the CAT gene

dc:source.dc:abstract: In blood, the hydrogen peroxide concentration is regulated by catalase. Decreased activity of catalase may lead to increased hydrogen peroxide concentration, which may contribute to the manifestation of age-related disease. The aim of this study is to examine association of decreased blood catalase activity and catalase exon mutations in patients (n=617) with diabetes (n=380), microcytic anemia (n=58), beta-thalassemia (n=43) and presbycusis (n=136) and in controls (n=295). Overall, 51 patients (8.3%) had less than half of normal blood catalase activity. Their genomic DNA was used for mutation screening of all exons and exon/intron boundaries with polymerase chain reaction-single-strand conformation polymorphism (PCR-SSCP) and PCR-heteroduplex analyses, and mutations were verified with nucleotide sequencing. Seven patients (type 2 diabetes (n=3), gestational diabetes (n=1), microcytic anemia (n=2)) had four novel catalase exon mutations namely, c.106_107insC, p.G36Afs*5(n=3, Hungarian type G1), c.379C>T, p.R127Y (n=2, Hungarian type H1), c.390T>C, p.R129L, (n=1, Hungarian type H2) and c.431A>T, p.N143V (n=1, Hungarian type H3). In patients with decreased blood catalase, the incidence of acatalasemia mutations was significantly high (P<0.0002) in microcytic anemia, type 2 and gestational diabetes. The four novel mutations were probably responsible for low blood catalase activity in 7/51 patients. In the remainder of the cases, other polymorphisms and epigenetic/regulatory factors may be involved.
dc:source.dc:creator: Nagy T
dc:source.dc:title: Further acatalasemia mutations in human patients from Hungary with diabetes and microcytic anemia.

evidence.rdfs:label: Nagy_Proband Male G1

evidence.dc:description: The proband was heterozygous for the frameshift variant in exon 2, Gly36AlafsTer5, that is predicted to cause NMD. It was observed in two patients with microcytic anemia and 1 patient with diabetes mellitus. It is absent from gnomAD. The proband is scored no points since the variant is in the heterozygous state.

evidence.detectionMethod: All exons, exon-intron junctions and 800bp of 5' UTR and 600bp of 3' UTR were sequenced from fibroblast DNA of proband.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The patient is noted to have oral gangrene (PMID: 3234345)

dc:source.dc:abstract: To search for the molecular defect of Japanese-type acatalasemia, we cloned the mutant catalase gene from a person with this deficiency. The nucleotide sequence of the mutant gene was determined for all exons, exon/intron junctions, and 5' and 3' flanking regions, and the findings were compared with the sequence from the normal gene. Seven base differences were found between the two genes. Among them, a G to A substitution at the fifth position of intron 4 (a splicing mutation) seemed most likely to be responsible for the defective catalase synthesis in the subject. To obtain suggestive evidence, we constructed chimeric genes that contained a segment of either the normal or mutant catalase gene, encompassing a 3' part of exon 4, the entire intron 4 and a 5' portion of exon 5, within the third exon of the human alpha-globin gene. When this chimeric gene construct was introduced into simian virus 40-transformed simian cells (COS-7), the transcript of the normal catalase/alpha-globin chimeric gene was spliced correctly, as revealed by Northern blotting and RNase mapping techniques. In contrast, the splicing of the mutant chimeric pre-mRNA occurred between the 5' donor site of the preceding intron and the 3' acceptor site of the intron containing the substitution, thereby skipping one entire exon sequence. Thus, the G to A transition at the fifth position of intron 4 of the catalase gene indeed severely limits the correct splicing of the RNA product. The same splice site mutation was found in the genomic DNA of another acatalasemic individual from an unrelated family. We suggest that this base substitution is the causal mutation of these cases of Japanese-type acatalasemia.
dc:source.dc:creator: Wen JK
dc:source.dc:title: Molecular analysis of human acatalasemia. Identification of a splicing mutation.

evidence.rdfs:label: Wen_Proband

evidence.dc:description: Expression studies using a chimeric gene with the partial sequence of CAT in COS-7 cells shows exon skipping due to this variant. Patients with this variant showed lack of catalase mRNA on Northern blot analysis (PMID: 3244798).

The proband was homozygous for +5 intronic variant in intron 4 that likely results in abnormal splicing. The authors conclude that this variant causes the catalase deficiency observed in the proband. An additional unrelated Japanese individual was also found to carry the same variant. It is reported at a frequency of 0.0003195 (1/3130 alleles) in the East Asian population in gnomAD. Kishimoto et al, 1992 (PMID: 1551654) report the same variant in 3 more Japanese patients and suggest that this variant is a founder mutation in the Japanese population. The variant is scored increased points.

evidence.detectionMethod: PCR-SSCP and PCR-heteroduplex analyses followed by sequencing was used to screen all 13 exons of the CAT gene
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Proband's catalase activity was determined to be 48%
evidence.rdfs:label: Nagy_Proband Male H3

evidence.dc:description: The proband was heterozygous for a missense variant, Asp144Val, which is erroneously reported in the paper as Asp143Val. No functional evidence for this variant is reported. It is absent from gnomAD. The proband is scored no points since the variant is in the heterozygous state.

evidence.detectionMethod: PCR-SSCP and PCR-heteroduplex analyses followed by sequencing was used to screen all 13 exons of the CAT gene
evidence.rdfs:label: Nagy_Proband Female H1

evidence.dc:description: The proband was heterozygous for the missense variant, Arg127Trp, which is erroneously reported in the paper as Arg127Tyr. No functional evidence for this variant is reported. It was also seen in another female patient with gestational diabetes. The variant is reported at a frequency of 0.00005430 (7/128910 non-Finnish European alleles) in gnomAD v3. The proband is scored no points since the variant is in the heterozygous state.

evidence.detectionMethod: Heteroduplex analysis revealed a mutation in exon2, which was then sequenced.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The proband is noted to have morbus Bleurel, a mental disorder synonymous with dementia precox
evidence.previousTestingDescription: The proband, her brother and nephew had a mean blood catalase activity±SD: 68.1±5.91 MU/l, with the reference range: 113.3±16.5 MU/l (n=1756).

dc:source.dc:creator: Góth L
dc:source.dc:title: A novel catalase mutation (a G insertion in exon 2) causes the type B of the Hungarian acatalasemia.

evidence.rdfs:label: Goth_Hungary B Proband

evidence.dc:description: The proband and two of her family members carried the heterozygous 1-bp insertion that caused a frameshift and early termination. Her catalase activity levels were about half of normal value. The authors conclude that the variant predisposes hypocatalsemic individuals to higher risk of conditions associated with high concentration of hydrogen peroxide. The proband is not scored any points as the variant is in the heterozygous state.

evidence.detectionMethod: Abnormal SSCP products were directly sequenced.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: The proband was diagnosed because of an adverse reaction to hydrogen peroxide during laryngectomy for laryngeal cancer. Catalase assay revealed red cell catalase activity was deficient: <0.05% of normal. It was half-normal in the proband's mother and three children.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Japanese-type acatalasemia is characterized by the almost total loss of catalase activity in red cells and is often associated with ulcerating oral lesions. A splicing mutation in intron 4 of catalase gene has so far been a sole disease-causing mutation found in Japanese-type acatalasemic patients. We report here a novel single base deletion in the catalase gene causing Japanese-type acatalasemia. The patient was a 72 year-old Japanese male. His maternal grandmother and his father were first cousins. Molecular analysis using non-RI PCR-SSCP analysis combined with direct sequencing revealed a deletion of the 358th thymine in exon 4 of the patient's catalase gene. The proband was a homozygote and his mother and his three children were heterozygotes for this mutation. The frame shift caused by the nucleotide deletion should alter the downstream amino acid sequence and introduce a new termination codon TGA 43 bp 3' to the mutation. Although the truncated peptide chain consisted of 133 amino acid residues might be translated in the patient's tissue, such an aberrant protein is expected to be extremely unstable and have no catalytic function at all. Our results suggest that Japanese-type acatalasemia is heterogeneous.
dc:source.dc:creator: Hirono A
dc:source.dc:title: A novel human catalase mutation (358 T-->del) causing Japanese-type acatalasemia.

evidence.rdfs:label: Hirono_Proband

evidence.dc:description: The proband was homozygous for the 1-bp deletion in exon 4 that causes a frameshift and leads to a PTC within exon 4. The resulting transcript is expected to undergo NMD.

evidence.detectionMethod: SSCP and heteroduplex analyses were followed by Sanger sequencing
evidence.previousTestingDescription: The proband and her sister had a mean blood catalase activity below 10 MU/l, with the reference range: 113.3±16.5 MU/l (n=1756).

dc:source.dc:abstract: Acatalasemia, a deficiency of enzyme catalase, is an autosomal recessive syndrome with an incidence of 5:106 in Hungary. We have examined the first Hungarian acatalasemic family for the disease-causing mutation. All exons of the catalase gene were screened by PCR-SSCP, PCR-heteroduplex, and nucleotide sequence analysis. The heteroduplex formation detected in exon 2 was verified by nucleotide sequence analysis. We found a GA insertion at nucleotide position 138, increasing the GA repeat number from 4 to 5. This GA insertion caused a frameshift in the amino acid sequence from position 68 to 133 and generated a TGA terminating codon at amino acid position 134. This truncated protein lacks the essential amino acid (histidine 74) in the active center. This finding can explain the decreased blood catalase activity in the Hungarian acatalasemic family.
dc:source.dc:creator: Góth L
dc:source.dc:title: Anovel catalase mutation (a GA insertion) causes the Hungarian type of acatalasemia.

evidence.rdfs:label: Goth_Hungary A Proband

evidence.dc:description: The proband and her sister were homozygous for the 2-bp insertion in exon 2 that causes a frameshift and early termination (Ile69Glufs*67). The resulting transcript is predicted to undergo NMD. Both sisters had Type II diabetes mellitus.

evidence.detectionMethod: Intron 4 of the CAT gene was amplified and sequenced
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The proband had poor oral hygiene, gingival pain, ulcers and necrosis. Deciduous teeth became loose by the age of 4y. All teeth were prematurely lost by the age of 9y.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Papillon–Lefevre syndrome was ruled out. Proband's catalase activity was 5.2 MU/l (4.6% of the normal range).

dc:source.dc:abstract: Acatalasemia is a rare genetic catalase deficiency that is inherited as an autosomal recessive trait. Although usually asymptomatic, a syndrome of oral ulcerations and gangrene may be present (Takahara's disease). In this report, we presented the diagnosis and 15-y periodontal treatments of an acatalasemia patient with Takahara's disease in China.
dc:source.dc:creator: Wang Q
dc:source.dc:title: Long-term follow-up evaluation of an acatalasemia boy with severe periodontitis.

evidence.rdfs:label: Wang_Proband

evidence.dc:description: The variant is reported to be de novo in the proband as the parents were tested negative. It is unlikely that the proband may be homozygous for this variant, and it is not clear if a deletion on the other allele was ruled out. The variant has been previously scored for report in Japanese individuals. It is not scored in this instance.

evidence.detectionMethod: PCR-SSCP and PCR-heteroduplex analyses followed by sequencing was used to screen all 13 exons of the CAT gene
evidence.rdfs:label: Nagy_Proband Male H2

evidence.dc:description: The proband was heterozygous for a synonymous variant, Arg130Arg, which is erroneously reported in the paper as Arg129Leu. No functional evidence for this variant is reported. It is absent from gnomAD. The proband is scored 0 points since the variant is in the heterozygous state.

evidence.detectionMethod: SSCP analysis revealed a mutation in the region of intron 6 to intron 7. Sequence analysis revealed the splice region variant.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: The proband, and 6 family members had a mean blood catalase activity±SD: 58.8±11.5 MU/L, with the reference range: 113.3±16.5 MU/L (n=1756).

dc:source.dc:abstract: Polymerase chain reaction-single strand conformation polymorphism (PCR-SSCP) screening was used for searching mutations of the catalase gene in two Hungarian hypocatalasemic families. A syndrome-causing mutation was found in a PCR product containing exon 7 and its boundaries. Nucleotide sequence analyses detected a G to T substitution at position 5 of intron 7. The effect of this splice site mutation was confirmed by Western blot analyses demonstrating a decreased catalase protein level in these patients. These findings represent a novel type (C) of catalase mutations in the Hungarian acatalasemic/hypocatalasemic patients.
dc:source.dc:creator: Góth L
dc:source.dc:title: A novel catalase mutation detected by polymerase chain reaction-single strand conformation polymorphism, nucleotide sequencing, and western blot analyses is responsible for the type C of Hungarian acatalasemia.

evidence.rdfs:label: Goth_Hungary C Proband

evidence.dc:description: The proband and 6 other family members were heterozygous for the splice region variant that is predicted to cause abnormal splicing. This variant is reported in the South Asian population at a frequency of 1% in gnomAD v2.1.1 and 0.5% in gnomAD v3. The proband is not scored any points as the variant is reported in the heterozygous state.

C57BL/6 mice endogenously expressing human catalase (hCAT) blocked ethanol-induced embryopathies compared to wild-type mice. In contrast, acatalasemic mice showed exacerbation of ethanol-induced embryopathies. Experiments with methanol-induced embryopathies did not yield similar results (PMID: 23207165 )

dc:source.dc:abstract: Reactive oxygen species (ROS) have been implicated in the mechanism of ethanol (EtOH) teratogenicity, but the protective role of the embryonic antioxidative enzyme catalase is unclear, as embryonic activity is only about 5% of maternal levels. We addressed this question in a whole embryo culture model. C57BL/6 mouse embryos expressing human catalase (hCat) or their wild-type (C57BL/6 WT) controls, and C3Ga.Cg-Cat(b)/J catalase-deficient, acatalasemic (aCat) mouse embryos or their wild-type C3HeB/FeJ (C3H WT) controls, were explanted on gestational day (GD) 9 (plug=GD 1), exposed for 24h to 2 or 4mg/mL EtOH or vehicle, and evaluated for functional and morphological changes. hCat and C57BL/6 WT vehicle-exposed embryos developed normally, while EtOH was embryopathic in C57BL/6 WT embryos, evidenced by decreases in anterior neuropore closure, somites developed, turning and head length, whereas hCat embryos were protected (p<0.001). Maternal pretreatment of C57BL/6 WT dams with 50kU/kg PEG-catalase (PEG-cat) 8h prior to embryo culture, which increases embryonic catalase activity, blocked all EtOH embryopathies (p<0.001). Vehicle-exposed aCat mouse embryos had lower yolk sac diameters compared to WT controls, suggesting that endogenous ROS are embryopathic. EtOH was more embryopathic in aCat embryos than WT controls, evidenced by reduced head length and somite development (p<0.01), and trends for reduced anterior neuropore closure, turning and crown-rump length. Maternal pretreatment of aCat dams with PEG-Cat blocked all EtOH embryopathies (p<0.05). These data suggest that embryonic catalase is a determinant of risk for EtOH embryopathies.
dc:source.dc:creator: Miller-Pinsler L
dc:source.dc:title: Embryonic catalase protects against ethanol embryopathies in acatalasemic mice and transgenic human catalase-expressing mice in embryo culture.

evidence.rdfs:label: Miller-Pinsler_Catalase Function

evidence.dc:description: The evidence is noted here, but not scored any points as the evidence does not pertain to a human phenotype. However, it may be scored upon expert review if cellular response to oxidative stress is deemed appropriate for the phenotype associated with acatalasemia.

Acatalasemic flies were extremely weak and died soon after eclosing. However, male and female flies carrying the catalase transgene were found to be viable. The authors conclude that decreased survival of the acatalasemic flies was due to the lack of functional catalase.

dc:source.dc:abstract: The enzyme catalase protects aerobic organisms from oxygen-free radical damage by converting hydrogen peroxide to molecular oxygen and water before it can decompose to form the highly reactive hydroxyl radical. Hydroxyl radicals are the most deleterious of the activated oxygen intermediates found in aerobic organisms. If formed, they can react with biological molecules in their proximity; the ensuing damage has been implicated in the increasing risk of disease and death associated with aging. To study further the regulation and role of catalase we have undertaken a molecular characterization of the Drosophila catalase gene and two potentially acatalasemic alleles. We have demonstrated that a previously existing allele, Catn4, likely contains a null mutation, a mutation which blocks normal translation of the encoded mRNA. The Catn1 mutation appears to cause a significant change in the protein sequence; however, it is unclear why this change leads to a nonfunctioning protein. Viability of these acatalasemic flies can be restored by transformation with the wild-type catalase gene; hence, we conclude that the lethality of these genotypes is due solely to the lack of catalase. The availability of flies with transformed catalase genes has allowed us to address the effect of catalase levels on aging in Drosophila. Though lack of catalase activity caused decreased viability and life span, increasing catalase activity above wild-type levels had no effect on normal life span.
dc:source.dc:creator: Griswold CM
dc:source.dc:title: Molecular characterization and rescue of acatalasemic mutants of Drosophila melanogaster.

evidence.rdfs:label: Griswold_Fly rescue

evidence.dc:description: The evidence is awarded reduced points. The score is awarded for rescue of catalase activity only. Since there is no clear phenotype associated with acatalasemia, the evidence on increased survival rate in rescued flies is not scored.
Flies with Cat-n1 or Cat-n4 showed little or no cross-reacting material on Western blot analysis and showed absence of Catalase activity. Flies that were acatalasemic were found to be less viable.
evidence.rdfs:label: Griswold_Fly model

evidence.dc:description: The evidence is awarded reduced points since the human phenotype associated with acatalasemia is variable; however, survival and longevity do not seem to be affected.

Acatalasemic mice grew normally and remained healthy and fertile. Tissues from homozygous knockout mice showed a reduced rate of hydrogen peroxide degradation compared to wild-type. Brian mitochondria were shown to be susceptible to oxidative phosphorylation. However, no clinical phenotypes were observed in mice, similar to acatalasemia in humans.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Catalase plays a major role in cellular antioxidant defense by decomposing hydrogen peroxide, thereby preventing the generation of hydroxyl radical by the Fenton reaction. The degree of catalase deficiency in acatalasemic and hypocatalasemic mice varies from tissue to tissue. They therefore may not be suitable for studying the function of this enzyme in certain models of oxidant-mediated tissue injury. We sought to generate a new line of catalase null mice by the gene targeting technique. The mouse catalase (Cat or Cas1) gene was disrupted by replacing parts of intron 4 and exon 5 with a neomycin resistance cassette. Homozygous Cat knockout mice, which are completely deficient in catalase expression, develop normally and show no gross abnormalities. Slices of liver and lung and lenses from the knockout mice exhibited a retarded rate in decomposing extracellular hydrogen peroxide compared with those of wild-type mice. However, mice deficient in catalase were not more vulnerable to hyperoxia-induced lung injury; nor did their lenses show any increased susceptibility to oxidative stress generated by photochemical reaction, suggesting that the antioxidant function of catalase in these two models of oxidant injury is negligible. Further studies showed that cortical injury from physical impact caused a significant decrease in NAD-linked electron transfer activities and energy coupling capacities in brain mitochondria of Cat knockout mice but not wild-type mice. The observed decrease in efficiency of mitochondrial respiration may be a direct result of an increase in mitochondrion-associated calcium, which is secondary to the increased oxidative stress. These studies suggest that the role of catalase in antioxidant defense is dependent on the type of tissue and the model of oxidant-mediated tissue injury.
dc:source.dc:creator: Ho YS
dc:source.dc:title: Mice lacking catalase develop normally but show differential sensitivity to oxidant tissue injury.

evidence.rdfs:label: Ho_Acatalasemic mice

evidence.dc:description: The evidence is scored reduced points since there is not a clear phenotype associated with Acatalasemia for recapitulation in animal models.

dc:description:
The relationship between CAT and Acatalasemia (also known as acatalasia), an autosomal recessive disorder, was evaluated using the ClinGen Clinical Validity Framework as of October, 2019 and reevaluated in September, 2022. No new evidence was has emerged that changes the overall score or classification of the curation. CAT encodes catalase, a peroxisomal antioxidant enzyme present in all aerobic cells. Acatalasemia is associated with absent or reduced catalase activity; however, patients exhibit no significant phenotypes. Since oxidative stress may have a role in the development of many chronic illnesses, acatalasemia is reported to be a risk factor for many diseases including type II diabetes mellitus, schizophrenia, cancer, arithritis and microcytic anemia. This curation considers acatalasemia as the disease entity, with the phenotype being reduced levels of catalase activity.

CAT was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive Acatalasemia in 1990 (Wen et al, PMID: 2308162). Variants in this gene include missense, splice region and frameshift variants. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data and experimental data. 
   
Summary of Case Level Data (5.5 points):
At least 3 patients from 3 publications have been reported with homozygous variants in CAT (PMIDs: 2308162, 11001624). Several individuals carrying the same variants in the Japanese and Hungarian populations are reported, which may be due to a founder effect. The mechanism of disease is expected to be homozygous loss of function. Heterozygous individuals show intermediate levels of catalase activity.
  
Summary of experimental data (4 points):
This gene-disease association is supported by mouse and fly models (PMID: 15178682, 8349109).  
  
In summary, the evidence to support the gene-disease relationship of CAT and Acatalasemia is moderate. While more evidence is needed to establish this relationship definitively, no convincing contradictory evidence has emerged.
